options: Do nothing immediately, but monitor the situation over the following week
Ask your colleague if she has been drinking
Report your concerns to your consultant
Check over all of your colleague's precriptions to ensure she has not made any mistakes
Do nothing, the situation is none of your business
questions: You are an F2. You know that one of your colleagues has been very stressed recently, and has told you that she has started drinking every night to relax. One morning you are concerned that your colleague smells of alcohol on the ward. List the following actions in order of most to least appropriate:
notes:
This question covers the Good Medical Practice Domain, 'Safety and Quality,' which states that you must take prompt action if you feel that patient safety is at risk.

The best option here is to be open with your colleague and to explain your concerns. This will allow you to discuss your concerns with them. You will then be able to act appropriately in terms of patient safety, and escalate the situation as required. It will also allow you support your colleague by helping her to seek appropriate support e.g from her GP.

Sharing your concerns with your consultant is a good option as well, but you should try to gather more information first, or try to make your colleague speak to the consultant themselves.

Checking your colleagues work and correcting her potential mistakes is not teh ideal solution, as allowing her to work under the influence of alcohol is a risk to patient safety. Monitoring her work is, however, a better option than ignoring your concerns, which is what options 1 and 5 involve.

GMC, Good Medical Practice, 2014. Paragraph 25.

Ask neighbouring patients in the ward to see if they had overheard anything

questions:
A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for cholecystitis. During the morning ward round, she discloses to the junior doctor that one of the doctors overnight had made sexual comments towards her and touched her inappropriately. The night medical team are no longer on shift, but the patient is able to describe the doctor.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This vignette describes a scenario in which a patient discloses sexual abuse by a member of the medical team. Reports must be taken seriously and careful documentation of the disclosure should be made. The incident should be raised with a senior colleague or consultant, and the local trust's reporting policy should be followed.

As there is not an imminent risk to others, contacting the police via 999 is not the most appropriate answer. The vignette describes that the night staff are no longer at work, so the patient is not currently at imminent danger.

'Ask neighbouring patients in the ward to see if they had overheard anything' is highly inappropriate. Firstly, it is not the role of the junior doctor to investigate the incident, but it also risks jeopardising the patient's confidentiality.

'Discuss the incident with the involved doctor at evening handover' is not appropriate. The junior doctor should not be approaching others or investigating the incident. Instead, they should report the incident to seniors and allow them to perform investigations. By approaching the doctor, future investigation may be jeopardised.

'Transfer the patient to another ward' is not the most appropriate answer as it does not address the concerns raised. Whilst it could be offered to move the patient, reporting the incident and making clear documentation is more appropriate.

'Call the involved doctor for their recall of events' is not an appropriate answer. Again, it is not the role of the junior doctor to investigate the incident; this should instead be left to the designated staff.

title: GMC: Sexual behaviour and your duty to report colleagues
body:
Actions that may be considered to be sexual behaviours:
  • Physical contact that is neither appropriate nor necessary for the care of a patient
  • Unprofessional and inappropriate sexual remarks

The Good Medical Practice has stated that doctors should not make any sexual advances or engage in a non-professional loving relationship with a patient or anyone close to them. Failure to abide by this may jeopardise patient care and the public trust in doctors. This may also lead to deregistration.

If you find that your colleague has engaged in a verbal or non-verbal sexual behaviour with a patient, you have a duty to report this because patient safety or care may be compromised. This should be done according to the GMC guidance on raising concerns as such:
  • Follow the trust policy if available
  • Ask advice from a senior e.g. direct supervisor, consultant, clinical director, GP partner
  • If you work in a general practice, seek advice from the GP partner. However, if the incident involves the partner, raise your concern outside the practice e.g. clinical governance lead.
  • Contact the General Medical Council to investigate if you feel that the response to the incident has been inadequate

When reporting this matter, only disclose pertinent details. Patient identity should be concealed unless patient safety becomes an issue (i.e. patient safety trumps patient confidentiality. Prior to breaking confidentiality, patient's consent should be obtained. If the patient declines to consent, the disclosure is only appropriate if it is in the public interest.

In the case of a sexual assault or a criminal activity such as rape or engaging in sexual intercourse with an underage patient, the police should be involved. In cases involving children, safeguarding team should be involved.

options: Prioritise the patients who've been handed over with life-threatening conditions and leave the other patients to be clerked when time permits
Ask the nurses to do basic clerkings and bleep you for drug-charts/management plans
Briefly clerk all patients in order of arrival to identify the ones who would need further input during the night
Decline to see patients until you have adequate senior support from your team
Phone the on-call consultant and inform him/her of the situation
questions:
You are a F2 doctor on medical nights. On arriving for hand over you are told there are 15 patients waiting to be clerked, including two patients in resus. The medical registrar is stuck on HDU with a poorly patient. The F1 doctor has called in sick.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is unfortunately not an uncommon scenario for junior doctors. Being able to deal appropriately with busy and stressful situations is one of the key requirements of specialist trainees.

The best response is to inform the on-call consultant of the situation. The patients are being admitted under his/her care and should be made aware of potential problems. The fact that the patients are in resus suggests managing by yourself may not be practical/safe.

The next best option is to prioritise and see the patients with life-threatening conditions. Clerking in all patients to identify the ill ones negates the benefit of the doctor-doctor handover and risks delaying interventions in sick patients.

Asking nurses to perform the duties of a doctor is clearly inappropriate. It may allow the sickest patients to be identified but this is not the role of a nurse and may risk patient safety.

Declining to see patients is the worst option as this risks patient safety the most. Whilst you may feel uncomfortable refusing to see sick patients is only going to further increase the risk to patients and is not in keeping with professional standards.

options: Complete an incident form after your lunch break
Ask them to leave the canteen
Do nothing as no name has been mentioned
Mention to them that they can be overheard
Secretly record what is happening on your phone so you can 'whistle-blow' to the local newspaper
questions:
You are a junior doctor in gastroenterology. One lunchtime you head to the canteen and sit down with colleagues. On the next table you overhear a group of nurses discussing a patient in voices loud enough to be heard by others. They do not mention the patient's name.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
Just because a name is not mentioned, does not necessarily mean that they have not said something which could make the patient in question identifiable, e.g. his medical diagnosis, appearance, etc. If this occurs, his confidentiality is still at risk of being broken. Even if you could not identify the patient from what is being said, the canteen is not the appropriate place to discuss patients. The best thing to do would be just to mention that they can be overheard. This should prompt them to stop.

The next best step is to ask them to leave the canteen. Completing an incident form doesn't achieve anything in the short term.

Taking no action when you observe something wrong is never a good option.

Secretly recording conversations about a patient and leaking them to a newspaper risks disseminating the confidential information further.

title: GMC guidance: Confidentiality
body:
The UK General Medical Council (GMC) provides guidelines on confidentiality to help doctors maintain trust with their patients and respect their right to privacy. Here is a summary of the key principles in GMC's guidance on confidentiality:
  • Patients' right to privacy: Doctors must respect patients' right to privacy and should not disclose their personal information without consent, unless required by law or justified by the public interest.
  • Obtaining consent: Whenever possible, doctors should obtain explicit consent from patients before disclosing their information. The consent should be informed and given freely, and patients should understand the potential consequences of sharing their information.
  • Anonymization: When using patient information for purposes such as teaching, research, or quality improvement, doctors should anonymize the data whenever possible to protect patients' identities.
  • Disclosures in the public interest: In exceptional circumstances, doctors may disclose patient information without consent if it is in the public interest, such as to prevent serious harm to others or in response to communicable diseases that pose a risk to public health.
  • Legal requirements: Doctors must comply with legal requirements to disclose patient information, such as court orders or statutory reporting obligations.
  • Confidentiality after death: Doctors should continue to respect patients' confidentiality even after their death, unless there are compelling reasons to disclose information.
  • Sharing information with the healthcare team: Doctors may share patient information within the healthcare team on a need-to-know basis to provide safe and effective care.
  • Record-keeping: Doctors should maintain accurate, up-to-date, and secure records to protect patient information and ensure its confidentiality.
  • Communicating with patients: Doctors should communicate openly and honestly with patients about their right to confidentiality and how their information may be used.
  • Working with third parties: When working with third parties, such as insurers or employers, doctors should ensure that they have appropriate consent from patients before sharing their information.
concept: A name does not have to be mentioned for a patient to be identified by another person. If this occurs, their confidentiality is still at risk of being broken

options: Reassure the son that CPR will not be stopped without his consent as he is the next of kin
Inform the son that his tone is unacceptable and call security
Ask the son if his father has ever conveyed his wishes regarding CPR
Offer to discuss this immediately in a private room with a senior colleague present
Inform the patient CPR is unlikely to be successful due to his father's age
questions:
A 98-year-old patient is brought into the hospital by ambulance unresponsive. His son had commenced cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and the paramedics had continued this. On arrival, the son immediately approaches you in the busy corridor and angrily insists his father receive 'full treatment' and CPR not be stopped. There is no advance directive in place and the patient does not have a do not attempt CPR form.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
Offer to discuss this immediately in a private room with a senior colleague present is the best option. A busy corridor in the emergency department is not the most appropriate place to have a sensitive conversation. It is important to have this conversation promptly as CPR is ongoing. For difficult conversations especially when the relative is already angry, it is sensible to have a senior colleague present.

Ask the son if his father has ever conveyed his wishes regarding CPR is an appropriate question. This information will help to make a decision about continuing CPR. However it would be more appropriate to have a conversation in a private place with a colleague present than in the corridor, and a more comprehensive conversation explaining the likely outcome of prolonged CPR is needed rather than just this simple question.

Inform the patient CPR is unlikely to be successful due to his father's age is true, but not a sensitive response to an upset relative who is keen for CPR to be continued. This could escalate the relative's anger.

Inform the son that his tone is unacceptable and call security is not a compassionate response to his understandable upset. This would be appropriate if the son became abusive, but is an unnecessary escalation at this stage.

Reassure the son that CPR will not be stopped without his consent as he is the next of kin is the least appropriate option as it is not true. CPR is a medical decision and though every effort should be made to involve the son in the decision, his consent is not required if it is deemed CPR is not in the best interests of the patient.

title: Decisions relating to cardiopulmonary resuscitation
body:
The following paragraph has been taken from the 'Decisions relating to cardiopulmonary resuscitation' guidelines from the Resuscitation Council:


Where a patient has not appointed a welfare attorney or made an advance decision, the treatment decision rests with the most senior clinician responsible for the patients care. Where CPR may re-start the patients heart and breathing for a sustained period, the decision as to whether CPR is appropriate must be made on the basis of the patients best interests (or benefit in Scotland). In order to assess best interests, where possible the views of those close to the patient must be sought, to determine any previously expressed wishes and what level or chance of recovery the patient would be likely to consider of benefit, given the inherent risks and adverse effects of CPR

options: Shout for help
Leave the room
Call security
Attempt to calm the patient down
Restrain the patient
Find another doctor to see the patient
Have the patient removed from the building
Evacuate the department
questions:
You are a junior doctor working a night shift in the Emergency department. You are clerking a patient who has injured his arm while out drinking. It is clear to you that he is intoxicated and he starts becoming angry and shouting for morphine. As you try to diffuse the situation by offering him morphine at the end of your consultation, he stands up and pushes you against the wall in a rage. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
In a situation where a patient becomes physically aggressive, it is most important to ensure that you are safe. This will involve getting help from others and removing yourself from harm's way. Another sensible option to do immediately is to call security who can offer you and other staff support to diffuse the situation.

Trying to deal with an angry and physically aggressive patient on your own is unwise. By the time the patient has physically attacked you you can safely assume that being able to calm the situation by yourself may not be possible. Restraining a patient should be a last resort, and not something you are expected to do yourself. Security may do this if deemed necessary. Removing the patient from the building may be necessary but again will be handled by security. You may have to see the patient yourself or find another doctor to see them once the situation has been dealt with, however immediately after the incident the first priority becomes safety for staff and other patients. It is unlikely to be necessary to evacuate the building because of this.

title: GMC: Ending your professional relationship with a patient
body:
The GMC guidelines contain information on ending your professional relationship with a patient. They state that;

You must only end a professional relationship with a patient when the breakdown of trust means you cannot provide good clinical care. This includes the patient being violent, threatening you or being abusive or the patient having stolen from you or the premises. It also includes the patient persistently acted inconsiderately or unreasonably or if they have made a sexual advance to you.

You should not end a relationship due to a complaint or due to resource implications.

Before you end the relationship you must warn the patient you are considering ending it and do what you can to restore the relationship. If this fails you must explore alternatives to ending it and discuss the situation with an experienced colleague or your employer.

When you end a relationship you must be satisfied that your reason is fair and does not discriminate. Then make sure the patient is told this is happening, and why. If practical do this in writing.
concept: If a patient becomes physically aggressive, ensuring your own safety is the priority in the first instance

options: Ask your registrar to come to the ward and speak to the relative
Inform the nurse in charge
Document in the patients notes what has happened
Tell the relative, despite being a qualified doctor, he has no right to look through the notes
Tell the relative if you see him looking in the notes again, you will ban him from the ward
questions:
You are a doctor working on the respiratory ward. You noticed one of the relatives of a patient looking through the patients notes. He claims that he is a doctor and this is fine for him to do. He then challenges the current management plan and insists on a host of other investigations to be carried out.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most important matter in this situation is to stop the relative from looking at the patient's notes. Therefore D is ranked highest. Being a qualified doctor does not give him the right to look through a patient's notes on the ward and could also breach patient confidentiality.

It is important for the nurse on the ward to be informed immediately so she looks out for it and prevents this from happening again.

A would be your next best option. This is a situation that can be dealt with by yourself or a nurse and hence escalating to a more senior level is not necessary for this situation. Therefore option A is ranked lower.

Although it is important to document such situations in the notes, option C does not deal with the problem in hand immediately.

E is the worst option. The situation can be dealt with in a much more polite manner and it is not necessary to ban this relative from seeing a patient.

title: Mental Capacity Act
body:
The Mental Capacity Act of 2005 came into force in 2007. It applies to adults over the age of 16 and sets out who can take decisions if a patient becomes incapacitated (e.g. following a stroke). Mental capacity includes the ability to make decisions affecting daily life, healthcare and financial issues.

The Act contains 5 key principles:
  • A person must be assumed to have capacity unless it is established that he lacks capacity
  • A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision unless all practicable steps to help him to do so have been taken without success
  • A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision merely because he makes an unwise decision
  • An act done, or decision made, under this Act for or on behalf of a person who lacks capacity must be done, or made, in his best interests
  • Before the act is done, or the decision is made, regard must be had to whether the purpose for which it is needed can be as effectively achieved in a way that is less restrictive of the person's rights and freedom of action

Assessment of capacity

The Act sets out a clear test for assessing whether a person lacks capacity. It is a 'decision-specific' and 'time-specific' test. An adult can only be considered unable to make a particular decision if:

1. He or she has an 'impairment of, or disturbance in, the functioning of the mind or
brain' whether permanent or temporary AND

2. He or she is unable to undertake any of the following
  • a. understand the information relevant to the decision
  • b. retain that information
  • c. use or weigh that information as part of the process of making the decision
  • d. communicate the decision made by talking, sign language or other means

No individual can be labelled 'incapable' simply as a result of a particular medical condition. Section 2 of the Act makes it clear that a lack of capacity cannot be assumed by a person's age, appearance, or any condition or aspect of a person's behaviour

Best interests

The following should be considered when assessing what is in someone's best interests:
  • 1. Whether the person is likely to regain capacity and can the decision wait.
  • 2. How to encourage and optimise the participation of the person in the decision.
  • 3. The past and present wishes, feelings, beliefs, values of the person and any other relevant factors
  • 4. Views of other relevant people

Lasting Powers of Attorney (LPAs)

The Act allows a person to appoint an attorney to act on their behalf if they should lose capacity in the future, replacing the current Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA). In addition to property and financial affairs the Act also allows people to empower an attorney make health and welfare decisions. The attorney only has the authority to make decisions about life-sustaining treatment if the LPA specifies that. Before it can be used an LPA must be registered with the Office of the Public Guardian

Advance decisions

Advance decisions can be drawn up by anybody with capacity to specify treatments they would not want if they lost capacity. They may be made verbally unless they specify refusing life-sustaining treatment (e.g. Ventilation) in which case they need to be written, signed and witnessed to be valid. Advance decisions cannot demand treatment

questions:
You are an F2 on a busy surgical firm. You are asked to request a CT abdomen for a patient who is thought to have diverticulitis. The consultant radiologist outright refuses to accept a referral from a ' house officer' and is rude in the process. Your other F2s have had similar experiences with this consultant.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
D. Discussing with the consultant first would allow you to explore any reasons for his behaviour and may help resolve the situation without needing to involve anyone else.

B. If talking to the member of staff in question has not been successful in resolving the issue, your next port of call would be your clinical supervisor.

C. This is less appropriate as you should always escalate within your own team first, rather than communicating directly with a senior member of another team.

A. Whilst such a formal complaint should not be first-line, it is better than simply ignoring the situation.

E. This would be inappropriate as you aren't tackling the issue and instead just avoiding it. You are also putting extra workload on your registrar which may compromise his ability to fulfil his job.

options: Phone the FY1 on the day team and ask her to take the bloods
Return to the hospital and take the bloods yourself
Wait until your next night shift and take the bloods then
Do nothing and wait for someone else to realise they need doing
Phone the ward nurses and inform them of what has happened and get them to ask one of the doctors on the ward
questions:
You are a junior doctor and have just completed an unusually busy night shift and returned home. Once home, you remember the registrar told you earlier that Mrs Potter, as patient on your ward, needed an urgent set of bloods doing which completely slipped your mind.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Option A is the best option as it addresses the situation in a prompt manner. It shows you have taken the initiative to rectify the situation and have spoken to an appropriate member of the team who has the capabilities to sort the bloods out.

Option E is ranked lower than A since it would be more desirable to speak directly to a doctor, that way you know that the bloods are more likely to be done instead of assuming a nurse will pass the information on.

Option B does ensure the patient gets their bloods taken, however it is not necessary for you to go all the way back to the hospital for a task that can be completed by another member of the team hence is ranked lower.

C and D are both poor options. The bloods were asked to be taken urgently and therefore waiting until your next shift is inappropriate and could compromise patient safety. However this option is slightly better than option D, where you are relying on others to determine whether the patient needs bloods when they have already been requested.
